2BC5D5FDA88741E287B4C478FCBC44C8.description: Solve a given problem by constructing and interpreting a concrete graph or pictograph.

37434AA4F6AA439FAD1631EADBEF55C5.description: Create a pictograph to represent a given set of data using one-to-one correspondence.

4672A08322074875AE8A127D6AC39FF8.description: Create a concrete graph to display a given set of data and draw conclusions.

FD617A3D3DE945EA93E4F9F27E189AFC.description: Answer questions pertaining to a given concrete graph or pictograph.

BAD64A5DF10A4FF593674DF0C7662D2D.description: Determine the common attributes of pictographs by comparing a given set of pictographs.

80C9207EFA2646369226ADBF91E7A1DE.description: Determine the common attributes of concrete graphs by comparing a given set of concrete graphs.

F66AA4C49E4645E0B1727F2A5816A32A.description:
Students will be expected to construct and interpret concrete graphs and pictographs
to solve problems.

06C44350C6784CA4865B381BC75AA6E4.description: Organize data as it is collected using concrete objects, tallies, checkmarks, charts, or lists.

E37562C7E86C4F70A34C9B294F0D13B1.description: Formulate a question that can be answered by gathering information about self and others.

98683BDE23474EA1A7FECA80896B94A2.description: Students will be expected to gather and record data about self and others to answer questions.

78A5F674F61F4EBA8A6D8C4D1FF277C2.description: Name the 2-D faces of a given 3-D object.

482587AD845C4970B4F2A42396420539.description: Compare and match a given 2-D shape, such as a triangle, square, rectangle, or circle, to the faces of 3-D objects in the environment.

9629AA27249B437E9D5F4EDA59B2AA5E.description: Students will be expected to identify 2-D shapes as part of 3-D objects in the environment.

65A9603725B8488F8CC0913FC35D09E5.description: Create a pictorial representation of a given 2-D shape.

17403E1C4A7943BA9676D7CDD7BD4832.description: Create a model to represent a given 2-D shape.

E92184B50D43479187D1C3A6F7F2B0DD.description: Identify and name examples of triangles, squares, rectangles, and circles found in the environment.

060699EBBEBB4B9AB60E993AD324ED62.description: Identify given 2-D shapes with different positions.

F81E0131CB804591B213F7C7C7B44B9C.description: Identify given 2-D shapes with different dimensions.

663DE6F949EF420285C73E70E6EC62CC.description: Identify common attributes of triangles, squares, rectangles, and circles from given sets of the same type of 2-D shapes.

F549B452BA4B42BEBA5376B2321DC828.description: Sort a given set of 2-D shapes and explain the sorting rule.

FD1D2BD279084D3185F464E66C61DFA5.description:
Students will be expected to recognize, name, describe, compare and build 2-D shapes, including
triangles, squares, rectangles, and circles.

BEF0864742A741C585B18CD4B2396A3F.description: Identify and name examples of cubes and other prisms, spheres, cones, cylinders, and pyramids found in the environment.

903218B25590459E8761B79BE6B82392.description: Create and describe a representation of a given 3-D object using materials such as modelling clay.

FE244E40E80C4E048250417234A8E19F.description: Identify and describe given 3-D objects with different positions.

F425999355624B50ADEF651A2C4DB5E4.description: Identify and describe given 3-D objects with different dimensions.

643E41DB6B064C558CB3408758162C0C.description: Identify common attributes of cubes and other prisms, spheres, cones, cylinders, and pyramids from given sets of the same 3-D objects.

01A265A69CC64D1381BC5F2FBD73E666.description: Sort a given set of 3-D objects and explain the sorting rule.

49D5093A1F1B4811B312E821D136733B.description:
Students will be expected to recognize, name, describe, compare, and build 3-D objects, including
cubes and other prisms, spheres, cones, cylinders, and pyramids.

4B294F8DCF7549E7AD8493AA7E8D73C2.description: Sort a given set of 3-D objects according to two attributes and explain the sorting rule.

7F9813478B954E64BB69DCC6844E8575.description: Sort a given set of 2-D shapes (regular and irregular) according to two attributes and explain the sorting rule.

A87DA7DD51C14D9B8FC6E4E66E7377A6.description: Identify and name two common attributes of items within a given sorted group.

85A2DFFD6F15409C89E1A5FD6B6BA116.description: Determine the differences between two given presorted sets and explain the sorting rule.

946973E59925429D804906F8A7E4380D.description:
Students will be expected to sort 2-D shapes and 3-D objects using two attributes and explain the
sorting rule.

DA2C5B4CE69E4CC58304A87F8B116931.description: Estimate and measure a given object using multiple copies of a non-standard unit and explain the results.

71322C12D1C240B3B5E9508432D50CD3.description: Count the number of non-standard units required to measure the length of a given object using multiple copies of a unit.

6D98B0B1AC9F4651AC3E9BBDBC35C83E.description: Explain why overlapping or leaving gaps does not result in accurate measures.

07D1832BA34A46C28CEED8A63579C85F.description:
Students will be expected to measure length to the nearest non-standard unit by using multiple
copies of a unit.

0A9650C7729842018C788EA5B0AE63D4.description: Compare and order the measure of two or more objects in ascending or descending order and explain the method of ordering.

130B2AD3BFD346CA91DCACD4BEB3D47B.description: Estimate, measure, and record the length, height, or mass of a given object using nonstandard units.

9B4138D088334A8B9AE9E6C42E80E138.description: Students will be expected to compare and order objects by length, height, and mass using nonstandard units and make statements of comparison.

0E0FA0196BCA409788D361BCFFE34592.description: Explain why the number of units of a measurement will vary depending upon the unit of measure used.

B87912C477534E01A5E412F21B43A14A.description: Estimate the number of non-standard units needed for a given measurement task.

3E24B72A8FAF4EADA1EEFC7B6C587474.description: Select a non-standard unit for measuring the length or mass of an object and explain why it was chosen.

B6FFA521C9A243919569C21689587A70.description: Explain why one of two given non-standard units may be a better choice for measuring the mass of an object.

5C860C8C15BD4B7FADE84ABE62C5C1B8.description: Explain why one of two given non-standard units may be a better choice for measuring the length of an object.

E441E08C6E2241A28E08FAF2318F08A9.description:
Students will be expected to relate the size of a unit of measure to the number of units (limited to
non-standard units) used to measure length and mass.

CB3E610D3D6B4237BFBF0C306969DD52.description: Solve a given problem involving time which is limited to the number of days in a week and the number of months in a year.

6A0FF1B85E6B41E691850F3BEF676F3B.description: Communicate the number of days in a week and the number of months in a year.

CE07F50B99F8416085D12ECFDF7746E6.description: Name and order the days of the week and months of the year.

FD8ED9546AD241B7A6B45EA0044D575D.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of the calendar and the
relationships among days, weeks, months, and years.

B31A0634BBCD4FCD97A4771F77E67CEF.description: Model inequalities using a variety of concrete representations and record the inequality.

FEEDCA876BFA4477BC53B92D1B419138.description: Model equalities using a variety of concrete representations and record the equality.

582259D78D004680AF2E277AC46C0146.description: Determine whether two sides of a given number sentence are equal (=) or not equal (≠). Write the appropriate symbol and justify the answer.

8FDE6F16AFF447CBBA8D2161C47AB0E4.description:
Students will be expected to record equalities and inequalities symbolically, using the equal
symbol or not equal symbol.

7E5A48F005C44C26A622774DA5AC3254.description: Construct and draw two unequal sets using the same object (same shape and mass) and explain the reasoning.

A5DFE7D48CA3416BA4F8A4BE6DAA383B.description: Determine whether two given quantities of the same object (same shape and mass) are equal by using a balance scale.

AA34DB2C5E1B41738D4EC43B55AA6035.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate and explain the meaning of equality and inequality by
using manipulatives and diagrams (0 to 100).

13662F109E844D3CB2E91E7A23B4FA0D.description: Determine missing terms in a given concrete, pictorial, or symbolic increasing pattern and explain the reasoning.

977708B4CDA542F0BF1A5F50985AC1EF.description: Identify and describe increasing patterns in the environment.

2EC7FF3AC65F4038B278CFC7402ED41A.description: Solve a given problem using increasing patterns.

51F1D33775A64AB786056FB549D72179.description: Represent a given increasing pattern using another mode.

3D467C4638324EE5BD929118B3E58CD1.description: Create an increasing pattern and explain the pattern rule.

CA5C3A3535E84991BA32632F8A2B2E1A.description: Explain the rule used to create a given increasing pattern.

CF8ADEBB794048849DFFD2E240C7C981.description: Identify errors in a given increasing pattern.

6F38F27040184D59963AFCE2F38B4D7E.description: Represent a given increasing pattern concretely and pictorially.

BB46ADB5EC28488FA7F60CE06C99E60B.description: Identify and describe increasing patterns in a variety of given contexts.

9EBBC262CB694B66820B2B63D3A0803A.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of increasing patterns by
describing, extending, and creating numerical patterns (numbers to 100) and non-numerical patterns
using manipulatives, diagrams, sounds, and actions.

12A6DBD421FF428FB7D42DCA7296FDF7.description: Compare two given repeating patterns, and describe how they are alike/different.

61D617947AB54DEAA67DDA37EF967B23.description: Translate a repeating pattern from one mode to another.

7394813D63134F2E98A0BEF5AC2D23DD.description: Predict an element of a given repeating pattern using a variety of strategies and extend the pattern up to the tenth element to verify the prediction.

8953C5BF07A24D9FAC16F7702B859D24.description: Create a repeating non-numerical pattern and explain the rule.

CF143803BDAE4077B7EFF94929FEAEE4.description: Describe and extend a given double attribute pattern.

A11A758A1E584CBDAF88D83EF9AFFC0E.description: Identify the core of a given repeating pattern.

856FEE142C914B1F8EC099D484F57FA5.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of repeating patterns (three to five
elements) by describing, extending, comparing, and creating patterns using manipulatives, diagrams,
sounds, and actions.

81AA2AD85AA74753A537660448E9CC39.description: Use and describe a personal strategy for determining the subtraction facts.

A6958A8608FD4B14852800C5DF83ED0B.description: Explain the think-addition strategy used to determine a basic subtraction fact.

129F606AFFA148618638506101E113BC.description: Quickly recall basic addition facts to 18 in a variety of contexts.

5AC6A672A08D48C8A113FC540DCF9185.description: Use and describe a personal strategy for determining a sum to 18.

D729DF3FC2F5447B820C56C54C1F925F.description:
Explain the mental mathematics strategy that could be used to determine basic addition
facts.

276F49F81F324D5CAA6C1640666194D4.description:
Students will be expected to apply mental mathematics strategies to quickly recall basic
addition facts to 18 and determine related subtraction facts.

D1B1C3908FBB4E5892ECF61EEBC85123.description: Recognize and create equivalent addition and subtraction number sentences.

2F2656268BC140198F436782B81C3CE9.description: Add a given set of numbers in two different ways and explain why the sum is the same.

386A8FFE981342DC9ECB653D885681CE.description: Model addition and subtraction using concrete materials or visual representations and record the process symbolically.

2C6F6C424C414A079F42CE54EC3612F7.description: Create an addition or a subtraction number sentence and a story problem for a given solution.

25FDBC9A825B451AACBC680CF63695EE.description: Match a number sentence to a given story problem.

F9E1DF2C71804FFC9C1AD4BCF02AE634.description: Solve a given story problem of any type by writing a number expression and combining the numbers to complete the number sentences.

A6F5968DD0AD4B7D934DFBCBA780B635.description: Solve a given story problem of any type by modelling it with materials or a diagram, and write a number sentence that represents the thinking in the solution.

81FBAA27927C4773A02834919ABF26E1.description: explaining and demonstrating that the order in which numbers are subtracted matters when finding a difference

764C81A3AD60446E92DE3AB9799F1485.description: explaining and demonstrating that the order in which numbers are added does not affect the sum

FF1295C46AB145E7A84EBB6129C955E9.description: creating and solving problems that involve addition and subtraction

3254D95F15C64555B48E86DED1C6B7F6.description: using personal strategies for adding and subtracting with and without the support of manipulates

3525CC1A166C4A65BC96F97ED3BA2B22.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of addition (limited to 1- and
2-digit numerals) with answers to 100 and the corresponding subtraction by:

E4D0215F46DD496D8625F6B423C94CF1.description: Subtract zero from a given number and explain why the difference is the same as the given Number.

DEB954D8779A4FA7878734C88FBAC12E.description: Add zero to a given number and explain why the sum is the same as the addend.

33AAFE578398461F80F276A8C8DF09CA.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate and explain the effect of adding zero to or
subtracting zero from any number.

80DCBDE2B0B549BB912CA795A1D2A1A5.description: Represent one unit if shown a pre-grouped model representing ten.

9F92F7C55CE449968C7C7E00952432B7.description: Explain why the value of a digit depends on its placement within a numeral.

FA425D8D8EEC4197B8C8E44B29B6E97E.description: Illustrate using proportional base-ten materials that a given numeral consists of a certain number of tens and a certain number of ones.

0779C4E6988949C2B8923033B66D862D.description: Illustrate using ten-frames and diagrams that a given numeral consists of a certain number of groups of ten and a certain number of ones.

518F51AE09594D269B45856D98184C93.description: Describe a given 2-digit numeral in at least two ways.

85924D5BD3194C928EE8E897725FCDEF.description: Count the number of objects in a given set using groups of 10s and 1s, and record the result as a 2-digit numeral under the headings of 10s and 1s.

0361E574C55243BEB21C8D61901789CE.description: Explain and show with counters the meaning of each digit for a given 2-digit numeral with both digits the same.

603BBB7EA38044DBACF507219E3341ED.description:
Students will be expected to illustrate, concretely and pictorially, the meaning of place
value for numerals to 100.

DE7993A0BAD841548ECC1C29D59FA8CA.description: Select between two possible estimates for a given quantity and explain the choice.

F3E43294DC3F4386BC265EF07D4F2638.description: Estimate the number of groups of ten in a given quantity using 10 as a referent.

880E35C522FB42DFAAD830BF950DBA1F.description: Estimate a given quantity by comparing it to a referent (known quantity).

2E800F1DF94148E7BAAE29190869FBAE.description: Students will be expected to estimate quantities to 100 by using referents.

F3E25AF26A3F40DD92663D7A74294DD1.description: Identify errors in a given hundred chart.

28301BCF268F4249AE152F8C8146EFEE.description: Identify missing numbers in a given hundred chart.

BFA0129BBA6040A1BB76E7DE14A95F38.description: Identify errors in a given ordered sequence.

E10CCE2D081F45A384F933A7D83DDA00.description: Compare and order a given set of numbers in ascending or descending order and verify the result using a hundred chart, number line, ten-frames, or by making references to place value.

E7ED9C971CA34324BA20B4287C27449F.description: Students will be expected to compare and order numbers up to 100.

3C4896A60EC240B188CD433562974CF8.description: Record in words a given number (0–20).

8BFFCC42642E4C019EC456703BF1632B.description: Read a number (0–100) given in symbolic or word form.

0C00CF850EAF495DA5520E85B655E5F6.description: Represent a given number using expressions (e.g., 24 + 6, 15 + 15, 40 – 10).

F1FF92DEC9F245A28B3CD3F140EA56E4.description: Find examples of a given number in the environment.

D18DDC85B7F94B1D8E290E4F6104F4DE.description: Represent a given number using tallies.

EC99406D283B4263A4F1CBB8C764B844.description: Represent a given number using coins (pennies, nickels, dimes, and quarters).

334B5953401E45A6B7C1D672C4EA4E26.description: Represent a given number using concrete materials, such as ten-frames and base-ten materials.

55428F2ECBCB4415879CAE41697788E4.description: Students will be expected to represent and partition numbers to 100.

2515985706804A7DB6A06D7BE6A5B8FC.description: Identify even and odd numbers in a given sequence, such as on a hundred chart.

0814A19BD3EB4FA0AF3F45AF8AC5496F.description: Use concrete materials or pictorial representations to determine if a given number is even or odd.

98DA1E5DD1D64159882BFC9DB987003B.description: Students will be expected to demonstrate if a number (up to 100) is even or odd.

9D4D0314B0854CA1B2C49E9AB461A900.description: Count quantity using groups of 2s, 5s, or 10s and counting on.

7410908835F14DD681863A0D5A90320C.description: Count a given sum of money with pennies, nickels, or dimes (to 100¢).

8D84E8E17C504E26981244182AD97FF7.description: Identify and correct errors and omissions in a given skip counting sequence.

1CAB6D61BE17450DA89B31B84E9C355F.description: Skip count by 10s, given any number as a starting point.

377921AACBA44EB384D9C24E57645F11.description: Extend a given skip counting sequence (by 2s, 5s, or 10s) forward and backward.

EE8CD6E879194128B538EAFBED884880.description: Extend counting sequence (by 1s), forward and backward.

EAA8447012804CB38608DA9FE866E289.description: 5s and 10s, forward and backward, using starting points that are multiples of 5 and 10 respectively to 100

D11648B1ACC943D18A5D57EA88349F59.description: 2s, forward and backward, starting from any point to 100

34B1CFC462614A05B7A621626C081B92.description: 1s, forward and backward, starting from any point to 200

9FF25E9CDB6C45D9AF6E254BBA99613B.description: Students will be expected to say the number sequence by
